00004  *  will be initialized.

00056 /* The outb and outw functions are used when accessing hardware devices. */
00057 
00058 /*! Wrapper for a byte out instruction. */
00059 inline static void
00060 outb(const short port_number, const char output_value)
00061 {
00062  __asm volatile("outb %%al,%%dx" : : "d" (port_number), "a" (output_value));
00063 }
00064 
00065 /*! Wrapper for a word out instruction. */
00066 inline static void
00067 outw(const short port_number, const short output_value)
00068 {
00069  __asm volatile("outw %%ax,%%dx" : : "d" (port_number), "a" (output_value));
00070 }
00071 
00072 void
00073 kprints(const char* string)
00074 {
00075  /* Loop until we have found the null character. */
00076  while(1)
00077  {
00078   register const char curr = *string++;
00079 
00080   if (curr)
00081   {
00082    outb(0xe9, curr);
00083   }
00084   else
00085   {
00086    return;
00087   }
00088  }
00089 }
00090 
00091 void
00092 kprinthex(const register long value)
00093 {
00094  const static char hex_helper[16]="0123456789abcdef";
00095  register int      i;
00096 
00097  /* Print each character of the hexadecimal number. This is a very inefficient
00098     way of printing hexadecimal numbers. It is, however, very compact in terms
00099     of the number of source code lines. */
00100  for(i=15; i>=0; i--)
00101  {
00102   outb(0xe9, hex_helper[(value>>(i*4))&15]);
00103  }
00104 }
00105 
00106 /*! Helper struct that is used to return values from prepare_process. */
00107 struct prepare_process_return_value
00108 {
00109  unsigned long first_instruction_address
00110   /*!< The address of the first instruction in the prepared process image. */;
00111  unsigned long page_table_address
00112   /*!< Will not be used until task 4. */;
00113 };
00114 
00115 /*! Copies an ELF image to memory and prepares a process. prepare_process
00116     does some checks to avoid that corrupt images gets copied to memory.
00117     However, the checks are not as thorough as the check in initialize.
00118     \return A prepare_process_return_value struct holding the first address
00119             of the process image and an address to the page table for
00120             the process. */
00121 static struct prepare_process_return_value
00122 prepare_process(const struct Elf64_Ehdr* elf_image
00123                  /*!< Points to the ELF image to copy. */,
00124                 const unsigned int       process
00125                  /*!< The index of the process that is to be created. */,
00126                 unsigned long            memory_footprint_size
00127                  /*!< Holds the maximum amount of memory, in bytes,
00128                       the image is allowed to use. */)
00129 {
00130  /* Get the address of the program header table. */
00131  int                program_header_index;
00132  struct Elf64_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf64_Phdr*)
00133                                        (((char*) (elf_image)) +
00134                                         elf_image->e_phoff));
00135  unsigned long      used_memory = 0;
00136  unsigned long      address_of_first_instruction = 0;
00137  struct prepare_process_return_value ret_val = {0, 0};
00138 
00139  /* First check that we have enough memory. */
00140  if (first_available_memory_byte + memory_footprint_size >= memory_size)
00141  {
00142   /* No, we don't. */
00143   return ret_val;
00144  }
00145 
00146  /* Scan through the program header table and copy all PT_LOAD segments to
00147     memory. Perform checks at the same time.*/
00148 
00149  for (program_header_index = 0;
00150       program_header_index < elf_image->e_phnum;
00151       program_header_index++)
00152  {
00153   if (PT_LOAD == program_header[program_header_index].p_type)
00154   {
00155    /* Calculate destination adress. */
00156    unsigned long* dst = (unsigned long *) (first_available_memory_byte + 
00157                                            used_memory);
00158 
00159    /* Check for odd things. */
00160    if (
00161        /* Check if the segment is contigous */
00162        (used_memory != program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr) ||
00163        /* Check if the segmen fits in memory. */
00164        (used_memory + program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz >
00165         memory_footprint_size) ||
00166        /* Check if the segment has an odd size. We require the segement
00167           size to be an even multiple of 8. */
00168        (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz&7)) ||
00169        (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz&7)))
00170    {
00171     /* Something went wrong. Return an error. */
00172     return ret_val;
00173    }
00174 
00175    /* First copy p_filesz from the image to memory. */
00176    {
00177     /* Calculate the source address. */
00178     unsigned long* src = (unsigned long *) (((char*) elf_image)+
00179      program_header[program_header_index].p_offset);
00180     unsigned long count = program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz/8;
00181 
00182     for(; count>0; count--)
00183     {
00184      *dst++=*src++;
00185     }
00186    }
00187 
00188 
00189    /* Then write p_memsz-p_filesz bytes of zeros. This to pad the segment. */
00190    {
00191     unsigned long count = (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz-
00192                            program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz)/8;
00193 
00194     for(; count>0; count--)
00195     {
00196      *dst++=0;
00197     }
00198    }
00199 
00200    /* Finally update the amount of used memory. */
00201    used_memory += program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz;
00202   }
00203  }
00204 
00205  /* Find out the address to the first instruction to be executed. */
00206  ret_val.first_instruction_address = first_available_memory_byte +
00207                                      elf_image->e_entry;
00208 
00209  /* Claim the memory. */
00210  first_available_memory_byte += memory_footprint_size;
00211  /* And round to nearest higher multiple of 4096 */
00212  first_available_memory_byte += 4096-1;
00213  first_available_memory_byte &= -4096;
00214 
00215  return ret_val;
00216 }

00218 /*! This is the last thing that is run when a process terminates. It performs
00219     all cleanup activities. Right now it is empty but in task 4 it will,
00220     for example, release the memory owned by the process. */
00221 static void
00222 cleanup_process(const int process /*!< The index, into process_table, of the
00223                                        terminating process. */)
00224 {
00225 }
00226 
00227 void
00228 initialize(void)
00229 {
00230  register int i;
00231 
00232  /* Loop over all threads in the thread table and reset the owner. */
00233  for(i=0; i<MAX_NUMBER_OF_THREADS; i++)
00234  {
00235   thread_table[i].data.owner=-1; /* -1 is an illegal process_table index.
00236                                      We use that to show that the thread
00237                                      is dormant. */
00238  }
00239 
00240  /* Loop over all processes in the thread table and mark them as not
00241     executing. */
00242  for(i=0; i<MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES; i++)
00243  {
00244   process_table[i].threads=0;    /* No executing process has less than 1
00245                                     thread. */
00246  }
00247 
00248  /* Initialize the ready queue. */
00249  thread_queue_init(&ready_queue);
00250 
00251  /* Go through the linked list of executable images and verify that they
00252     are correct. At the same time build the executable_table. */
00253  {
00254   const struct executable_image* image;
00255 
00256   for (image=ELF_images_start; 0!=image; image=image->next)
00257   {
00258    unsigned long      image_size;
00259 
00260    /* First calculate the size of the image. */
00261    if (0 != image->next)
00262    {
00263     image_size = ((char *) (image->next)) - ((char *) image) -1;
00264    }
00265    else
00266    {
00267     image_size = ((char *) ELF_images_end) - ((char *) image) - 1;
00268    }
00269 
00270    /* Check that the image is an ELF image and that it is of the
00271       right type. */
00272    if (
00273        /* EI_MAG0 - EI_MAG3 have to be 0x7f 'E' 'L' 'F'. */
00274        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG0] != 0x7f) ||
00275        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG1] != 'E') ||
00276        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG2] != 'L') ||
00277        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_MAG3] != 'F') ||
00278        /* Check that the image is a 64-bit image. */
00279        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_CLASS] != 2) ||
00280        /* Check that the image is a little endian image. */
00281        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_DATA] != 1) ||
00282        /* And that the version of the image format is correct. */
00283        (image->elf_image.e_ident[EI_VERSION] != 1) ||
00284        /* NB: We do not check the ABI or ABI version. We really should
00285           but currently those fields are not set properly by the build
00286           tools. They are both set to zero which means: System V ABI,
00287           third edition. However, the ABI used is clearly not System V :-) */
00288 
00289        /* Check that the image is executable. */
00290        (image->elf_image.e_type != 2) ||
00291        /* Check that the image is executable on AMD64. */
00292        (image->elf_image.e_machine != 0x3e) ||
00293        /* Check that the object format is corrent. */
00294        (image->elf_image.e_version != 1) ||
00295        /* Check that the processor dependent flags are all reset. */
00296        (image->elf_image.e_flags != 0) ||
00297        /* Check that the length of t   he header is what we expect. */
00298        (image->elf_image.e_ehsize != sizeof(struct Elf64_Ehdr)) ||
00299        /* Check that the size of the program header table entry is what
00300           we expect. */
00301        (image->elf_image.e_phentsize != sizeof(struct Elf64_Phdr)) ||
00302        /* Check that the number of entries is reasonable. */
00303        (image->elf_image.e_phnum < 0) ||
00304        (image->elf_image.e_phnum > 8) ||
00305        /* Check that the entry point is within the image. */
00306        (image->elf_image.e_entry < 0) ||
00307        (image->elf_image.e_entry >= image_size) ||
00308        /* Finally, check that the program header table is within the image. */
00309        (image->elf_image.e_phoff > image_size) ||
00310        ((image->elf_image.e_phoff +
00311          image->elf_image.e_phnum * sizeof(struct Elf64_Phdr)) > image_size )
00312       )
00313 
00314    {
00315     /* There is something wrong with the image. */
00316     while (1)
00317     {
00318      kprints("Kernel panic! Corrupt executable image.\n");
00319     }
00320     continue;
00321    }
00322 
00323    /* Now check the program header table. */
00324    {
00325     int                program_header_index;
00326     struct Elf64_Phdr* program_header = ((struct Elf64_Phdr*)
00327                                          (((char*) &(image->elf_image)) +
00328                                           image->elf_image.e_phoff));
00329     unsigned long      memory_footprint_size = 0;
00330 
00331     for (program_header_index = 0;
00332          program_header_index < image->elf_image.e_phnum;
00333          program_header_index++)
00334     {
00335      /* First sanity check the entry. */
00336      if (
00337          /* Check that the segment is a type we can handle. */
00338          (program_header[program_header_index].p_type < 0) ||
00339          (!((program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_NULL) ||
00340             (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD) ||
00341             (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_PHDR))) ||
00342          /* Look more carefully into loadable segments. */
00343          ((program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD) &&
00344            /* Check if any flags that we can not handle is set. */
00345           (((program_header[program_header_index].p_flags & ~7) != 0) ||
00346            /* Check if sizes and offsets look sane. */
00347            (program_header[program_header_index].p_offset < 0) ||
00348            (program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr < 0) ||
00349            (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz < 0) ||
00350            (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz < 0) ||
00351           /* Check if the segment has an odd size. We require the
00352              segement size to be an even multiple of 8. */
00353            (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz&7)) ||
00354            (0 != (program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz&7)) ||
00355            /* Check if the segment goes beyond the image. */
00356            ((program_header[program_header_index].p_offset +
00357              program_header[program_header_index].p_filesz) > image_size)))
00358         )
00359      {
00360       while (1)
00361       {
00362        kprints("Kernel panic! Corrupt segment.\n");
00363       }
00364      }
00365 
00366      /* Check that all PT_LOAD segments are contigous starting from
00367         address 0. Also, calculate the memory footprint of the image. */
00368      if (program_header[program_header_index].p_type == PT_LOAD)
00369      {
00370       if (program_header[program_header_index].p_vaddr !=
00371           memory_footprint_size)
00372       {
00373        while (1)
00374        {
00375         kprints("Kernel panic! Executable image has illegal memory layout.\n");
00376        }
00377       }
00378 
00379       memory_footprint_size += program_header[program_header_index].p_memsz;
00380      }
00381     }
00382 
00383     executable_table[executable_table_size].memory_footprint_size =
00384      memory_footprint_size;
00385    }
00386 
00387    executable_table[executable_table_size].elf_image = &(image->elf_image);
00388    executable_table_size += 1;
00389 
00390    kprints("Found an executable image.\n");
00391 
00392    if (executable_table_size >= MAX_NUMBER_OF_PROCESSES)
00393    {
00394     while (1)
00395     {
00396      kprints("Kernel panic! Too many executable images found.\n");
00397     }
00398    }
00399   }
00400  }
00401 
00402  /* Check that actually some executable files are found. Also check that the
00403     thread structure is of the right size. The assembly code will break if it
00404     is not. */
00405 
00406  if ((0 >= executable_table_size) || (1024 != sizeof(union thread)))
00407  {
00408   while (1)
00409   {
00410    kprints("Kernel panic! Can not boot.\n");
00411   }
00412  }
00413 
00414  /* Start running the first program in the executable table. */
00415 
00416  /* Use the ELF program header table and copy the right portions of the
00417     image to memory. This is done by prepare_process. */
00418  {
00419   struct prepare_process_return_value prepare_process_ret_val = 
00420    prepare_process(executable_table[0].elf_image,
00421                    0,
00422                    executable_table[0].memory_footprint_size);
00423 
00424   if (0 == prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address)
00425   {
00426    while (1)
00427    {
00428     kprints("Kernel panic! Can not start process 0!\n");
00429    }
00430   }
00431 
00432   /* Start executable program 0 as process 0. At this point, there are no
00433      processes so we can just grab entry 0 and use it. */
00434   process_table[0].parent=-1;    /* We put -1 to indicate that there is no
00435                                     parent process. */
00436   process_table[0].threads=1;
00437 
00438   /* We need a thread. We just take the first one as no threads are running or
00439      have been allocated at this point. */
00440   thread_table[0].data.owner=0;  /* 0 is the index of the first process. */
00441 
00442   /* We reset all flags and enable interrupts */
00443   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rflags=0x200;
00444 
00445   /* And set the start address. */
00446   thread_table[0].data.registers.integer_registers.rip =
00447    prepare_process_ret_val.first_instruction_address;
00448 
00449   /* Finally we set the current thread. */
00450   cpu_private_data.thread_index = 0;
00451  }
00452 
00453  /* Set up the timer hardware to generate interrupts 200 times a second. */
00454  outb(0x43, 0x36);
00455  outb(0x40, 78);
00456  outb(0x40, 23);
00457 
00458  /* Now we set up the interrupt controller to allow timer interrupts. */
00459  outb(0x20, 0x11);
00460  outb(0xA0, 0x11);
00461 
00462  outb(0x21, 0x20);
00463  outb(0xA1, 0x28);
00464 
00465  outb(0x21, 1<<2);
00466  outb(0xA1, 2);
00467 
00468  outb(0x21, 1);
00469  outb(0xA1, 1);
00470 
00471  outb(0x21, 0xfe);
00472  outb(0xA1, 0xff);
00473 
00474  kprints("\n\n\nThe kernel has booted!\n\n\n");
00475  /* Now go back to the assembly language code and let the process run. */
00476 }
00477 
00478 /*! Allocate one thread. The allocated thread is not initialized.
00479     Rip and rflags need to be set for the thread to start properly.
00480     \return An index into thread_table or -1 if no thread could be allocated.
00481  */
00482 static inline int
00483 allocate_thread(void)
00484 {
00485  register int i;
00486  /* loop over all threads and find a free thread. */
00487  for(i=0; i<MAX_NUMBER_OF_THREADS; i++)
00488  {
00489   /* An owner index of -1 means that the thread is available. */
00490   if (-1 == thread_table[i].data.owner)
00491   {
00492    return i;
00493   }
00494  }
00495 
00496  /* We return -1 to indicate that there are no available threads. */
00497  return -1;
00498 }
00499 
00500 extern void
00501 system_call_handler(void)
00502 {
00503  register int schedule=0;
00504  /*!< System calls may set this variable to 1. The variable is used as
00505       input to the scheduler to indicate that scheduling is not necessary. */
00506 
00507  /* Reset the interrupt flag indicating that the context of the caller was
00508     saved by the system call routine. */
00509  thread_table[cpu_private_data.thread_index].data.registers.from_interrupt=0;
00510 
00511  switch(SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax)
00512  {
00513   case SYSCALL_PAUSE:
00514   {
00515    register int  tmp_thread_index;
00516    unsigned long timer_ticks=SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rdi;
00517 
00518    /* Set the return value before doing anything else. We will switch to a new
00519       thread very soon! */
00520    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=ALL_OK;
00521 
00522    if (0 == timer_ticks)
00523    {
00524     /* We should not wait if we are asked to wait for less then one tick. */
00525     break;
00526    }
00527 
00528    /* Get the current thread. */
00529    tmp_thread_index=cpu_private_data.thread_index;
00530 
00531    /* Force a re-schedule. */
00532    schedule=1;
00533 
00534    /* And insert the thread into the timer queue. */
00535 
00536    /* The timer queue is a linked list of threads. The head (first entry)
00537       (thread) in the list has a list_data field that holds the number of
00538       ticks to wait before the thread is made ready. The next entries (threads)
00539       has a list_data field that holds the number of ticks to wait after the
00540       previous thread is made ready. This is called to use a delta-time and
00541       makes the code to test if threads should be made ready very quick. It
00542       also, unfortunately, makes the code that insert code into the queue
00543       rather complex. */
00544 
00545    /* If the queue is empty put the thread as only entry. */
00546    if (-1 == timer_queue_head)
00547    {
00548     thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next=-1;
00549     thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.list_data=timer_ticks;
00550     timer_queue_head=tmp_thread_index;
00551    }
00552    else
00553    {
00554     /* Check if the thread should be made ready before the head of the
00555        previous timer queue. */
00556     register int curr_timer_queue_entry=timer_queue_head;
00557 
00558     if (thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data>timer_ticks)
00559     {
00560      /* If so set it up as the head in the new timer queue. */
00561 
00562      thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data-=timer_ticks;
00563      thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next=curr_timer_queue_entry;
00564      thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.list_data=timer_ticks;
00565      timer_queue_head=tmp_thread_index;
00566     }
00567     else
00568     {
00569      register int prev_timer_queue_entry = curr_timer_queue_entry;
00570 
00571      /* Search until the end of the queue or until we found the right spot. */
00572      while((-1 != thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.next) &&
00573            (timer_ticks>=thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data))
00574      {
00575       timer_ticks-=thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data;
00576       prev_timer_queue_entry=curr_timer_queue_entry;
00577       curr_timer_queue_entry=thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.next;
00578      }
00579 
00580 
00581      if (timer_ticks>=thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data)
00582      {
00583       /* Insert the thread into the queue after the existing entry. */
00584       thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next=
00585        thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.next;
00586       thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.next=tmp_thread_index;
00587       thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.list_data=timer_ticks-
00588        thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data;
00589      }
00590      else
00591      {
00592       /* Insert the thread into the queue before the existing entry. */
00593       thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next=
00594        curr_timer_queue_entry;
00595       thread_table[prev_timer_queue_entry].data.next=tmp_thread_index;
00596       thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.list_data=timer_ticks;
00597       thread_table[curr_timer_queue_entry].data.list_data-=timer_ticks;
00598      }
00599     }
00600    }
00601    break;
00602   }
00603 
00604   case SYSCALL_TIME:
00605   {
00606    /* Returns the current system time to the program. */
00607    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=system_time;
00608    break;
00609   }
00610 
00611 #include "syscall.c"
00612   default:
00613   {
00614    /* No system call defined. */
00615    SYSCALL_ARGUMENTS.rax=ERROR_ILLEGAL_SYSCALL;
00616   }
00617  }
00618 #include "scheduler.c"
00619 }
00620 
00621 extern void
00622 timer_interrupt_handler(void)
00623 {
00624  /* Increment system time. */
00625  system_time++;
00626 
00627  /* Check if there are any thread that we should make ready.
00628     First check if there are any threads at all in the timer
00629     queue. */
00630  if (-1 != timer_queue_head)
00631  {
00632   /* Then decrement the list_data in the head. */
00633   thread_table[timer_queue_head].data.list_data-=1;
00634 
00635   /* Then remove all elements including with a list_data equal to zero
00636      and insert them into the ready queue. These are the threads that
00637      should be woken up. */
00638   while((-1 != timer_queue_head) &&
00639         /* We remove all entries less than or equal to 0. Equality should be
00640            enough but checking with less than or equal may hide the symptoms
00641            of some bugs and make the system more stable. */
00642         (thread_table[timer_queue_head].data.list_data<=0))
00643   {
00644    register int tmp_thread_index=timer_queue_head;
00645    /* Remove the head element.*/
00646    timer_queue_head=thread_table[tmp_thread_index].data.next;
00647 
00648    /* Let the woken thread run if the CPU is not running any thread. */
00649    if (-1 == cpu_private_data.thread_index)
00650    {
00651     cpu_private_data.thread_index = tmp_thread_index;
00652    }
00653    else
00654    {
00655     /* Or insert it into the ready queue. */
00656     thread_queue_enqueue(&ready_queue, tmp_thread_index);
00657    }
00658   }
00659  }
00660 #include "pscheduler.c"
00661 
00662  /* Acknowledge interrupt so that new interrupts can be sent to the CPU. */
00663  outb(0x20, 0x20);
00664 }
Generated on Sun Feb 14 19:30:51 2010 for 02333 Tasks B3 and A3 by  1.5.6
